Key Match Events: The game was a 7-0 shutout loss for the Detroit Tigers, their worst shutout loss since Game 1 of the 1945 World Series.
A horrific start by the Tigers led to a 5-0 deficit in the first inning.
Steven Kwan led off with a double off the wall in right, and Holton walked David Fry, setting up the Guardians' early scoring.
José Ramírez hit a grounder down the line that caught McKinstry in between hops, getting past him and allowing Kwan to score.
Reese Olson gave up a three-run homer to Lane Thomas in the first inning.
The Tigers stranded two runners in the first against Cleveland's Tanner Bibee.
The Guardians pounced on the Tigers' early mistakes, scoring 5 runs in the first inning.
The Tigers couldn't get anything going on offense against Bibee or Cleveland's vaunted bullpen, which combined for 4 1/3 hitless innings.
Detroit hitters struck out 13 times, and the Tigers didn’t get a runner past first over the final five innings.
Pre-Game Insights: The Tigers came in feeling confident after going 31-13 since Aug. 11 to earn a postseason berth before sweeping AL West champion Houston in the wild-card round.

Manager A.J. Hinch’s decision to not use a traditional starter in Game 1 of the AL Division Series backfired as Tyler Holton failed to record an out and reliever Reese Olson gave up a three-run homer to Lane Thomas in the first inning.
Post-Match Reflections: Hinch said, “When they punch you with five in the first, it’s hard to overcome.”
Hinch added, “I thought Holton rarely gives up back-to-back anything, let alone like guys getting on base. And we never recovered.”
Parker Meadows said, “We have to keep playing our game against them. They’ve been really good all year and we know that, but we’ve been pretty good, as well.”
Meadows added, “We’re very confident because of what Tarik Skubal has been able to do all year. We just have to flush this one quick.”
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Tigers have Tarik Skubal on deck for Game 2, who led the AL in wins, ERA and strikeouts.
The left-hander will start Game 2 on Monday following a day of rest the Tigers could use after starting the week in Texas, spending a day in Michigan and the weekend in Ohio.
